On 19/12/2007, krn_2k <krn_2k@...> wrote:
>
> I was asking about a subversion repository or equivalent for the
> project more from the point of view of accessing existing and
> submitting new patches (be they bug fixes, speed improvements or major
> branching extensions like parallel/hyper neat). The beauty of a
> source control system is that you do not have to take time out someday
> to merge bits of the other releases into the main code, anybody could
> instead apply patches against the main release or release patches
> anywhere.

I have been thinking about whether to use CVS or SVN. I really like
the support for these repositories in Eclipse (www.eclipse.org), and
even if you make it very restricted access it can still be useful to
see detailed revision histories for files. It's another level of
transparency (after providing the source code) that can aid in using
the codebase and confirming/finding bugs.

In general I think the bug reporting system in sourceforge is the
ideal place to be reporting bugs and/or suggesting small patches. The
only alternative is to open up CVS to anyone who asks and who wants to
submit a patch, which may lead to chaos. It's probably a moot point
for SharpNeat given that there aren't more than a handful of people a
year wanting to submit a patch - but the possibility exists of the
codebase getting out of control.

The other aspect I'm fuzzy on is CVS/SVN support in MS Visual Studio
or SharpDevelop. Actually the more I use Eclipse the more my opinion
of VS lessens. Right now I'm torn between using the .Net framework
which I prefer over the Java SDK, and the poor (by comparison) IDE's
in the .Net world. Although I haven't seen Visual Studio 2008 yet -
but I'm not holding my breath for any major improvements!

I was wondering what current users (user?) of SharpNeat would think
about switching to a Java code base - David I know you're doing CPPN
stuff, would a switch to Java be a major issue for your work? I guess
you could continue on the existing code base anyway. Also IKVM
(www.ikvm.net) allows you to use Java frameworks in a .Net environment
- my only concern there though is there will be a slight loss of
performance (but not that much).

Oh and the other issue is that of support for generics/templates. Both
Java and .Net have this now but in the Java world generics are still
just language level constructs - they are not supported in the VM and
hence there is no performance benefit(e.g. from avoidance of
boxing/unboxing of value types), only a coding efficiency/compactness
benefit. I understand this issue is being considered in the Java
world, but it's not here now, today.


Colin.
